title: How to Paint Sheet Metal for Home Decorating

steps.headline: Texturize the surface of the sheet metal.
steps.description: Analyze the surface of the sheet metal. If the sheet metal is smooth to the touch, you will need to texturize it before painting. Create a rough surface on the sheet metal. Using high-grit sandpaper or steel wool, rub the surface of the sheet metal. This will allow the paint to adhere to the metal. Create a light, even texture on the surface and avoid making deep grooves in the metal. To remove stubborn rust spots, use a drill with a circular wire brush attachment.

steps.headline: Clean the sheet metal.
steps.description: A clean surface will allow the paint to adhere better to the sheet metal and will create a more attractive finish. Spray the sheet metal with white vinegar and wipe it down with a clean rag. The vinegar's acidity will further abrade the sheet metal. Spray the metal with compressed air. This will remove any dust and dirt from the surface of the sheet metal.

steps.headline: Protect areas you don't want painted.
steps.description: If there are areas of the sheet metal that will not be painted, cover them with painter's tape or masking tape.

steps.headline: Choose a paint created specifically for metal.
steps.description: Choose an acrylic latex semi-gloss, a gloss enamel or an oil-based semi-gloss paint. Paints designed for use on metal will resist rust and will be more durable than traditional wall paints.

steps.headline: Apply paint with a brush or roller.
Spray paint the sheet metal as an alternative to painting with a brush.Shake the spray paint can vigorously for 1 or 2 minutes before painting the sheet metal.

tyn: Drill with a circular wire brush attachment
text:
Prepare the Sheet Metal Texturize the surface of the sheet metal. Analyze the surface of the sheet metal. If the sheet metal is smooth to the touch, you will need to texturize it before painting. Create a rough surface on the sheet metal. Using high-grit sandpaper or steel wool, rub the surface of the sheet metal. This will allow the paint to adhere to the metal. Create a light, even texture on the surface and avoid making deep grooves in the metal. To remove stubborn rust spots, use a drill with a circular wire brush attachment. Clean the sheet metal. A clean surface will allow the paint to adhere better to the sheet metal and will create a more attractive finish. Spray the sheet metal with white vinegar and wipe it down with a clean rag. The vinegar's acidity will further abrade the sheet metal. Spray the metal with compressed air. This will remove any dust and dirt from the surface of the sheet metal. Protect areas you don't want painted. If there are areas of the sheet metal that will not be painted, cover them with painter's tape or masking tape. Paint the Sheet Metal Choose a paint created specifically for metal. Choose an acrylic latex semi-gloss, a gloss enamel or an oil-based semi-gloss paint. Paints designed for use on metal will resist rust and will be more durable than traditional wall paints. Apply paint with a brush or roller. Sheet metal paint is available in both spray paint and brush-on options. Both types of paint work well for home decorating purposes. Choose a brush or roller size appropriate for your sheet metal project. If the sheet metal is large, select a wide brush or roller; if the sheet metal is small, choose a smaller brush or roller. For best paint control, hold the brush at the base of the handle near the bristles. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-6Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-6Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-6Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-6Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Apply 2 coats of the paint, allowing the first coat to dry completely before applying the second coat. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7c/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-6Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-6Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7c/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-6Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-6Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Spray paint the sheet metal as an alternative to painting with a brush.Shake the spray paint can vigorously for 1 or 2 minutes before painting the sheet metal. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Test the nozzle before applying paint to the sheet metal. Spray a small amount of paint on a newspaper or piece of cardboard to ensure the nozzle is working correctly and sprays paint evenly. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Apply spray paint to the sheet metal. Hold the spray paint can 12 to 24 inches (30.4 to 60.9 cm) from the surface. Spray in a quick, smooth and even pattern until the surface is covered. For best results, keep the can parallel to the sheet metal surface and spray in a back and forth motion over the surface. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet3-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet3-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet3-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet3-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}
sentences: Prepare the Sheet Metal Texturize the surface of the sheet metal.
Analyze the surface of the sheet metal.
If the sheet metal is smooth to the touch, you will need to texturize it before painting.
Create a rough surface on the sheet metal.
Using high-grit sandpaper or steel wool, rub the surface of the sheet metal.
This will allow the paint to adhere to the metal.
Create a light, even texture on the surface and avoid making deep grooves in the metal.
To remove stubborn rust spots, use a drill with a circular wire brush attachment.
Clean the sheet metal.
A clean surface will allow the paint to adhere better to the sheet metal and will create a more attractive finish.
Spray the sheet metal with white vinegar and wipe it down with a clean rag.
The vinegar's acidity will further abrade the sheet metal.
Spray the metal with compressed air.
This will remove any dust and dirt from the surface of the sheet metal.
Protect areas you don't want painted.
If there are areas of the sheet metal that will not be painted, cover them with painter's tape or masking tape.
Paint the Sheet Metal Choose a paint created specifically for metal.
Choose an acrylic latex semi-gloss, a gloss enamel or an oil-based semi-gloss paint.
Paints designed for use on metal will resist rust and will be more durable than traditional wall paints.
Apply paint with a brush or roller.
Sheet metal paint is available in both spray paint and brush-on options.
Both types of paint work well for home decorating purposes.
Choose a brush or roller size appropriate for your sheet metal project.
If the sheet metal is large, select a wide brush or roller; if the sheet metal is small, choose a smaller brush or roller.
For best paint control, hold the brush at the base of the handle near the bristles.

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Test the nozzle before applying paint to the sheet metal.
Spray a small amount of paint on a newspaper or piece of cardboard to ensure the nozzle is working correctly and sprays paint evenly.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/09\/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/09\/Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Paint-Sheet-Metal-for-Home-Decorating-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Apply spray paint to the sheet metal.
Hold the spray paint can 12 to 24 inches (30.4 to 60.9 cm) from the surface.
Spray in a quick, smooth and even pattern until the surface is covered.
For best results, keep the can parallel to the sheet metal surface and spray in a back and forth motion over the surface.
